11:10 am
BE11:10am

Neil Woodford has been fired from his flagship fund and its assets are to be liquidated after administrators abandoned attempts to relaunch the frozen investment vehicle.

The decision by Link Fund Solutions to wind up the Woodford Equity Income Fund is likely to spell the end of Mr Woodford’s 30-year career managing money for the public, during which he became the UK’s most high-profile fund manager.

Mr Woodford immediately hit back. “This was Link’s decision and one I cannot accept, nor believe is in the long-term interests [of investors],” he said in a statement.

Link, the income fund’s authorised corporate director, said on Tuesday the fund — which was suspended in June in the face of mounting redemption requests — would be wound up.

BE11:11am

https://www.ft.com...-bfa4-b25f11f42901

The windup will be a messy process but it's been largely anticipated.

I would refer you to the Link FCA liquidity analysis from April 2019 which stated that 33% of the portfolio would take more than 180 days to liquidate. https://www.fca.org.uk/publication/correspondence/lf-woodford-equity-income-fund-letter-tsc.pdf

So much of this is already in the WPCT price

Woodford Patient Capital Trust plc (WPCT:LSE): Last: 34.25, down 3.4 (-9.04%), High: 36.00, Low: 33.60, Volume: 5.30m
Grouchmonkey Morning all
#REF! wow some members of the ROTR really get annoyed that this free service won't wear their legal risk...

Blank canvas Fletcher Christian just threw his toys out of his pram
Bluesky21 Wirecard - the articles (understandably) don't allow comments, so I am just coming in here and congratulations the FT team on a great job. Objective, thorough and fearless - in the best tradition of the FT
11:14 am
BE11:14am

Here's Stifel's Iain Scouller

BE11:14am

There was always a high likelihood that investors in the Woodford Equity Income Fund (WEIF) would not wish to stay in the fund once it re-opened, and we think that today’s news of a wind up and return of cash to investors gives investors clarity now, rather than having to wait until the end of the year to see the outcome. The Woodford Patient Capital (WPCT) board has put out a brief holding statement reiterating they are undertaking a review of the management arrangements and will make a further announcement in due course.

With Woodford Investment Management effectively in wind-down, we think the board of WPCT does now need to appoint a new manager as a matter of necessity, given the trust does not pay an annual management fee (only a performance fee) and Woodford IM will have little revenue to pay its expenses now that there is no fee income from WEIF. We think that any new manager of WPCT will expect a conventional annual management fee to be paid going forward.

BornCynic What is the law BE? Can the FT be sued for posts made by people who are not employees?
Bluesky21 sorry, "congratulate the FT team"
BE11:15am

(@Fletcher: you've misunderstood quite a lot. @BornCynic: yes.)

11:15 am
BE11:15am

We also think the wind-up of WEIF increases the likelihood that the board of WPCT will decide to put the trust into run-off, with investments realised gradually over a number of years and cash returned to investors once the bank debt (£111m at 26/09/19) is repaid. We commented on the bank debt issue in a note last Thursday (link here).

WPCT opened down 3p in trading this morning to an all time low of 35p - in the short term, we think the shares may see some bounce, given the increased likelihood that a new manager will be appointed to WPCT and a run-off of the trust appears more likely. However, we would expect the price to continue to be volatile, given the question marks around the realisable value of the portfolio, especially the unquoteds and issues around WPCT’s need to reduce leverage

BornCynic Wow - tough law.
cheeckychappy @BE - will be interesting to see if the FT's latest Wirecard missive ends up on the Daily Mail website a la Jemima Kelly....then they really will end up with a problem on their hands.
Tom Dalgleish That has to be a YES BC, and so are we liable
Bluesky21 WeWork, Wirecard, Woodford - basically don't invest in anything that starts with a "W"?
BE11:16am

And spinning back to that note re debt last Thursday .....

Blank canvas so, down to serious business now
BornCynic @Tom - anyone is welcome to sue me. You'll burn more in legal fees than you'll get in damages.
BE11:17am

One of the biggest factors in corporate failures has been excessive leverage, so it is always a factor to monitor closely. This trust has been running with leverage of 15% to 20% of NAV in recent years (Figure 1). In normal circumstances this should be quite manageable, however Woodford Patient Capital (WPCT) is clearly not in normal times and we think a close eye needs to be kept on leverage, given the debt facility expires in January 2020, unless renewed.

Irish HF guy Woodford is the Investment Manager appointed by the ACD, and they can also fire him which they finally did. 3 months notice and then liquidation process can occur. I reckon investors will get 50%-60% of their funds by the end of Jan 2020 and as for the rest, forced seller is not a great place to be so probably another 10%-15% decline in NAV and the remaining 30% or so will be paid out during the remainder of 2020. I really do feel for the Investors as I reckon they will lose another 10% of NAV on top of the 20% since suspension. @Bluesky21, agreed, who knew W was so toxic.. Mind you when you can get $6m for the right to We !
VV75 Probably also negative again for Hargreaves, since they had been promoting the fund prominently.
11:17 am
BE11:17am

We assume that by 31/12/19, there is a sale of a number of unquoteds from WPCT, resulting in a cash inflow which can be used to pay down debt. The manager says there are negotiations underway on a number of company-specific transactions, together with interest from parties looking at acquiring portfolios of assets. We also assume that a new bank facility will be negotiated, although at more onerous terms than the current LIBOR+1.5% cost. As 2019 draws to a close, if neither of these developments materialise, this would be a cause for significant concern.

Casper @BE - can't comment on Dan's Wirecard article for some reason. In hte article he says "subsidiaries inDubai and Ireland that do not file public financial statements." Tell him he can find lots of financial data on Wirecard's Irish units here https://search.cro.ie/company/CompanySearch.aspx For example, search Wirecard and view the list of submissions for "WIRECARD UK AND IRELAND LIMITED". There are account details with hundreds of pages available for a few Euro.
Bluesky21 @VV75 - HL, for what it is worth, said on their FY19 call in Aug that the effects have been limited
BE11:18am

There are clearly a number of scenarios for potential outcomes for WPCT over the next year. It continues to be a high risk investment in our view given leverage, management company issues and the illiquid portfolio. Given the current inability to make new investments and difficulties in making follow-on investments due to the trust being close to its leverage upper limit (19% of NAV vs 20% maximum at time of investment), we think the board should seriously consider adopting a 'run-off' strategy where investments are gradually realised over a number of years and cash is returned to investors, once the bank debt is repaid. There is also a question over the viability of Woodford Investment Management and the board have already said they are reviewing management arrangements. If a new manager is appointed, we think it would be helpful for portfolio companies if some of the existing management team transfer over to any new manager, in order to maintain continuity and knowledge of portfolio investments.

Bluesky21 People who redeem from Woodford Income Focus (not suspended) or HL multimanager funds tend to stay on the platform
VV75 @bluesky, I wouldn't be surprised if there is a claim by clients in their future
Bluesky21 And supposedly often reinvested into other "Wealth 50" funds

Iain has been the best analyst by far on the Woodford fallout. I hope he doesn't mind us overquoting him and hope the readers go to Stifel direct with any follow-up questions.

Bluesky21 @VV75 - if advisors can be sued for bad investments, half the City is at risk

Marston's PLC (MARS:LSE): Last: 113.23, down 8.77 (-7.19%), High: 117.90, Low: 109.20, Volume: 4.11m
Irish HF guy Kent did not get their redemption funds request as that was what caused the fund suspension. 250gbp out the door was too much when they had 8% liquidity in the 1-7 day bucket and a redemption request for 7% of the fund!

BE11:27am

Profit flatlining, which is no surprise. It's food rather than wet led though, which is less expected.

Brutto @Irish HF guy: join that club as well....I do think the debt reduction will take some time, though, so I'm not counting on more than the divi.
Sails @Blank - try signing out of and back into FT Alphaville (or the FT)
BE11:27am

Here's Liberum to summarise.

marktime Just read the Wirecard stuff. Wow.
BE11:27am

rading in food led outlets remains challenging with 0.1% LFL growth in Destination & Premium pubs over the year, which should have been better given the soft comparatives. While the Premium Pubs and Bar brands performed well, the more food-led outlets found the going tough and the outlook remains challenging with covers under pressure.

Wet led performance was more encouraging with LFL growth of 1.9% over the year and 5.4% over the last 10 weeks, an acceleration from Q3 which was hampered by the very challenging comparatives (weather and FIFA World Cup in Summer 2018). Marston's beer volumes +1.0%.

Overall, Group Turnover was up 3%, including LFL sales growth of 1.9%, to £1.2bn in FY19E, with EBITDA broadly flat (c£221m) and underlying PBT of £101m.

Net debt ended in line with expectations at £1.4bn (increase of £13m vs FY18E) equivalent to 6.3x Net Debt/EBITDA (vs 6.2x FY18E)

FitzLions Thanks Irish and Crackle. Bold move by KCC to seek to redeem its entire investment in one go.
1st Lt. Fletcher Christian No comment on the Woodford Income Fund. I assume this will close too.
11:28 am
BE11:28am

Premium / destination is 43% of ebit vs 29% from taverns .....

cracklenpop Kent reportedly was the only local authority pension fund invested in Woodford IM
BE11:29am

......... which makes Marston's more like Restaurant Group than EI?

BE11:29am

Back to Liberum.

11:29 am
BE11:29am

Following a review of operational plans, the company now expects to invest an additional £2-3m in pub training, localised pub team incentive initiatives and local digital marketing investment. This is to improve the service quality to support spend per head and maintain covers in the food-led outlets.

There is a £3m step up in securitized interest payments.

53rd week is equivalent to £5m EBITDA, £3m PBT

Strong interest in tenanted, licensed and unlicensed properties means guidance for annual disposal proceeds has been increased from £40m to £70m per annum. This does not include any brand disposals, contrary to press reports.

BE11:29am

We have factored in slower LFL growth outlook (1.5% to 1.0%) as well as additional £3m margin investment and higher interest charges. This results in 4% cut to PBT from £105m to £101m in FY19E and 9% cut from £111m to £101m in FY20E.

BE11:30am

It is understandable that following a strong run there would be some profit taking off the back of these earnings cuts. While PBT growth looks set to stagnate over the next few years, the prospect of debt reduction should transfer value to equity shareholders. The estate remains well-maintained and largely freehold based (93%), which combined with a greater focus on operational improvements should bode well for longer term prospects. The shares are inexpensive on CY20E EV/EBITDA of 8.8x, PE of 8.4x with FCF yield of 9.7%. Meanwhile the dividend of 7.5p looks secure, giving a yield of c6.8%. The last reported NAV was 151p per share (26% discount).

We reduce our TP to 125p (from 130p) based on a blend of SOTP/ROIC:WACC/DCF

11:30 am
BE11:30am

And Barclays

BE11:30am

Weak pre-close trading update that should be taken negatively, with guidance below consensus PBT expectations. The main positive is lower Net Debt expected in FY20. Trading update: Destination & Premium trading is soft, with LFLs of 0.1% (time period not specified, so unclear if last 10 weeks or FY19). Drink sales are said to be stronger than food sales, but D&P margins are expected to be “below last year” (Barclays forecasts -20bps) reflecting increased margin investment and higher labour costs as a % of sales. Trading in Taverns has been stronger, with LFLs +5.4% in the last 10 weeks (better weather). Overall, the company expect EBITDA to be broadly flat vs FY18 (£223m vs Barclays FY19E £226m), and underlying PBT is anticipated at 'around £101m'. This compares with Bloomberg consensus FY19 PBT of £105m, and Barclays £105.7m, a fairly significant downgrade given the company recently updated the market with their Q3 statement. Net Debt is expected to be £1,399m vs BBG consensus £1,394m and Barclays £1,389m. For 2020, Marston’s say they have reviewed their operational plans and are “proposing to invest an additional £2-3 million in pub training, localised pub team incentive initiatives and digital marketing investment”. Disposal proceeds expectations have been raised higher to £70m from £40m. Whilst the investment may be sensible for the medium term, the result of this is that the group expect “profit before tax in 2020 to be at a similar level to 2019”, ie around £101m, “reflecting growth in underlying operating profits offset by increased disposal activity, additional pub investment and higher interest charges”. Bloomberg FY20E PBT is £110m vs Barclays £109m. Bridging the £8-9m difference vs current FY20 expectations appears to be c£4m flow through from the FY19 miss, c£2-3m disposal acceleration, and the £2-3m training/marketing investment. We currently assume c£37m Net Debt reduction in FY20, and further disposals should help, but we still note the high Debt/EBITDA starting point of 6.1x FY19E. This leaves little margin for error if trading deteriorates further. Valuation (existing forecasts): FY20E: PE 8.5x, EV/EBITDA 9.1x, yield 6.1%, FCF yield 6.9%.

Bluesky21 I think Hargreaves Lansdown was £2bn in Woodford towards the end
Bluesky21 I would be surprised if there are that many institutions in there
marktime The trust we place in auditors continues to be eroded
BE11:31am

And Canaccord, which takes profit.

11:31 am
BE11:32am

Today's pre-close trading statement revealed that good Brewing and Taverns performances, helped by the late September warm weather, have not been enough to offset the decline in Destination & Premium (D&P) where food sales continue to struggle. As a consequence, we are cutting our EPS (Dil. Adj.) by 3.7% to 13.2p for FY19E, by 9.3% to 13.1p for FY20E and by 11.7% to 13.5p for FY21E. We are cutting our target price to 110p (was 125p) to reflect the downgrade and reducing our recommendation to HOLD from Buy - the +6.5% dividend yield, recent M&A activity and a 153p NAV should act as a floor to the share price. As the share price is up 36% YTD, profit-taking is inevitable today, we believe.

BE11:32am

At yesterday's close, Marston's is trading on a PE of 9.2x, an EV/EBITDA of 9.8x and a dividend yield of 6.3% for FY19E, changing to 9.3x, 9.2x and 6.3% for FY20E. At a group level, our new 110p target price values Marston’s on 8.3x PE, 9.5x EV/EBITDA, an 8.7% FCF yield and 7.0% dividend yield, changing to 8.4x, 8.9x, 12.7% and 7.0% for FY20E. The target PE multiple is still below the five and ten-year averages for the group. The share price is underpinned by a NAV of 153p for FY19E which looks conservative in light of recent sector activity: Fullers/Asahi, Ei Group/Stonegate and Greene King/CK Asset Holdings.

2s10s @marktime: are the auditors responsible for overseeing liquidity management?
undefined
Bluesky21 Woodford AUM was reported to be £4.3bn in May, so HL on its own is already about half
11:33 am
BE11:33am

Sticking with profit warnings

A. M. (morning all.)
Vesuvius PLC (VSVS:LSE): Last: 363.00, down 53.4 (-12.82%), High: 394.40, Low: 358.80, Volume: 1.40m
marktime If you have ever read an auditor's opinion and terms of business they seem to be responsible for absolutely
Irish HF guy @2s10s & marktime, liquidity risk management is the responsibility of the ACD, Link and if you read the FCA letter it is shocking that Link let Woodford get away with a liquidity profile such as was evident in WEIF.
VV75 Renishaw too please, if we have time later.
marktime nothing
Bluesky21 @cracklepop - Derbyshire, West Yorkshire and Dyfed councils all in WPCT https://www.theguardian.com/business/2019/jun/16/council-staff-pensions-at-risk-from-woodford-investments
BornCynic @marktime - I used to be an audit senior at KPMG. My (potentially libelous) advice - don't rely on those things.
Bluesky21 Fair bet these will be in the unlisted funds too
cracklenpop @Fitz *bold* is one way of describing Kent's actions
BE11:35am

None of it surprising. Continued weakening of demand for crucibles

11:35 am
BE11:36am

Steel market going bad globally, though China led of course

LK Hyman Wasn't there a letter in the FT recently criticising Vesuvius for shutting an operation in Spain? Strange where tips come from!
BE11:36am

Morgan Stanley:

Bluesky21 @BornCynic - having been on the other side of the table (though with every other Big 4 except KPMG) I completely agree
BE11:36am

esuvius has pre released its 3Q trading update guiding to FY19 EBITA of £180m - £190m (midpoint £185m). This is -8% – -3% (-5% at mid point of the range) vs current consensus EBITA and -10% – -5% (-8% at the mid point of the range) vs MSe. Reason for the warning: (i) challenging market environment has continued into H2 2019; (ii) end markets continuing to weaken further, particularly in the EMEA region; (iii) both Steel and Foundry divisions have been impacted by a continuing weakening in their key end markets; (iv) Steel producers have announced annualised production cuts equivalent to c.4% of 2018 volumes since the end of June; (v) IHS Markit has lowered its 2019 light vehicle production forecasts and it now expects a 5.6% decline versus 2018 compared to a 4.2% decline previously.Conclusion: [...] given recent growth developments in World Ex.China Steel Production and the typical short cycle characteristics of Foundry end markets (typically high correlation with global PMIs), this pre-release should not come as a huge surprise. Vesuvius reiterated its 12.5% long-term margin target but noted that "this is unlikely to be delivered until we revert to long-term growth trends". We expect mid single digit cuts to consensus on the back of this pre-release.

Irish HF guy @BornCynic, I was with Deloitte and I would agree. The auditors report is only to the members/shareholders and they just say the FS are true & fair. Look at the Thomas Cook financials, 3bn of net liabilities and the directors signed off on going concern and the auditors just concur. Mind you when auditors do put an emphasis of matter in a set of FS, it usually is a death sentence for the company concerned and is usually after the fact
11:37 am
BE11:37am

And Numis.

BE11:37am

The shares appear to offer value and the balance sheet is relatively robust (2019 ND/EBITDA 1.1x). However, looking into a downturn there are few indicators as to how deep/long the slowdown will be (our 23% reduction in 2020 numbers demonstrates Vesuvius volatility). Hence, timing wise, we see it as too early to get involved rather than necessarily the wrong price.

BE11:38am

As an 'early cycle canary' statement will focus minds on the other
cyclicals including RHI Magnesita (additional cost saving opportunities) as Vesuvius' closest peer, Morgan Advanced with its Molten Metal Systems albeit only 10% of EBIT.

marktime The average partner share about £750,000 ... what do you think motivates them, honesty or client relations
11:38 am
BE11:38am

And RBC.

BE11:38am

Some market weakness was expected, hence we cut our 2019/2020 EPS 3%/8% on October 8. With the shares trading on a 2020 PE of 8.1x on
our estimates (pre-warning), versus a ten-year average of 11.4x we would suggest that some of it was priced in. In light of the valuation, we would
suggest that the shares down 10% (0840 BST) is an over-reaction. The valuation alongside operating upside remain the shares’ key attractions. We still
see management's 12.5% operating margin target as achievable (prior peak 16%), and they reiterated on the analyst call that this was achievable once
markets return to growth. However, a tougher economic backdrop is clearly pushing out its achievement.

cracklenpop @Bluesky https://www.ft.com/content/445f05cb-7096-329c-ab82-2ee88ab0add1?accessToken=zwAAAW3PNXCokc9EXwXLcJYynNOrgi7oirCt0Q.MEUCIQCclO1JzMAdP_RrNoqsO-JT6FmZnzqyjaUAqzhZC8DkfQIgcdW1boZkWvUxkqY_HZy5ZTYHC9gswk3LtGAmA-rAPCc&sharetype=gift?token=25018891-44ae-4cde-ba9b-72846765b16b

BE11:45am

Renishaw 1Q20 trading statement
Renishaw reported 1Q20 revenue of £124.6m, -19% yoy (vs. 1Q19 of £154m).
Metrology business reported revenue of £119.7m, -19% yoy (vs. 1Q19 of £147.4m), while healthcare business of £4.9m vs. 1Q19 of £6.6m. Adjusted profit before tax came in at £4.3m, which includes a restructuring provision of £2m (vs. 1Q19 of £32.6m). The first quarter of 2019 benefitted from a number of large orders from end-user manufacturers of consumer electronic products in the APAC region which have not been repeated this year. 19% Implied cut to 1H20 consensus top-line
Applying the same seasonality split for 1Q/2Q19 implies 1H20 Group revenue of £240m, implying a 19% cut to 1H20 consensus top-line. The same analysis on PBT implies greater than 70% cut to adjusted PBT (£12m vs. consensus at £43m).
China at the core of the weakness
The company reiterated that they expect trading conditions to remain challenging through the remainder of the financial year, driven by the global macroeconomic environment. With China accounting for 20% of top-line, we believe slowdown in the Chinese market, and electronics in particular, could be main driver of the weak results. Softness in the metrology business could be a read-through for Hexagon, though weakness in Hexagon had already been flagged for the last quarter.
Valuation: Sell, PT £34.90
We expect a negative reaction to the results. First half results will be realised on 30 Jan 2020. Our price target is based on a blend of DCF (WACC 8.4%, LTG 4.4%) and relative 2019E peers P/E multiples of 19.8x.

LK Hyman @BE Someone worrying about news leakage and then a double dip on Renishaw? It didn't leak to me, alas!
BE11:46am

And Stifel.

BE11:46am

Our continued sell case on Renishaw over recent months has been predicated on two concerns:
1) that the weakness in demand that the group has been seeing in its Asian markets would start to spread to other regions, notably Germany (an important geography for the group) and 2) that given the group's traditional reluctance to trim spending (particularly on R&D) in periods of softer demand, volume weakness could have a sharp negative impact on profitability. The Q1 update released today (a week earlier than scheduled), strongly suggests that both trends are now coming through, although little colour was provided on geographic trends. Q1 sales are down 19% year on year, and at the headline profit level negative operational gearing makes for a much more dramatic decline (almost 90% YoY). Margins are down to mid single digits in the period. In addition, a £2m charge taken in the quarter to close an Additive Manufacturing site suggests some weakening of faith in what was meant to be the next great growth driver for the group. The balance sheet remains strong, and the core Metrology franchise is an excellent one, which we believe will recover in time - but for now consensus forecasts need to be reduced fairly substantially in our view, and we expect the stock to remain under pressure.

That said, the share price reactions could set the tone for the upcoming 3Q results season and reveal the extent to which investors are willing to ‘buy’ on guidance cuts, particularly for Renishaw which is earlier cycle / more Asia exposed and started to see decelerating growth from mid-2018 onwards. We note recent market reactions such as for Yaskawa in Japan which was flat on the day despite reporting greater than 25% profit cut to guidance and for Fastenal in the US which saw its shares increase by 17% on the day of its slight beat.

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Bellway delivered a 3% increase in PBT with growth in volumes and ASP partly offset by a c110bps decline in the margin. While trading in the new financial year has been positive and new divisions should provide a tailwind to volumes in FY20, a further moderation in the margin leads us to reduce our PBT forecasts by 5-6%. We have rolled our target price forward to 3,550p but after a c40% rise in the share price year to date, and reflecting our forecast trim, we move our recommendation to Hold from Add.

BE11:54am

Recent trading has been robust, with reservation rates ahead by 4% since 1st August. The forward order book currently comprises 5,190 homes with a value of £1.31bn. This is down on the £1.47bn from last year, partly reflecting a relatively strong period of construction and completions. As the dynamics of little or no house price inflation and ongoing build cost pressures continue, and the non-repeat of the benefits of the Nine Elms development (c80bps margin benefit in FY19), we have reduced our ASP and margin expectations. We now forecast a 19.8% operating margin in FY20 (previously 20.5%) which overall leads to a c6% reduction in our PBT estimate to £640m. For FY21 we reduce by 5% to £660m.

BE11:55am

The shares have risen by 39% in the year to date, some way ahead of the sector average of +26%. They are trading on a P/NAV of 1.26x for CY20 vs 1.54x sector average. The ROE of c17% compares to 18% for the sector with a dividend of 4.5% vs 7.5%.

11:56 am
BE11:57am

Having already released most of the key financial figures in the group’s July trading update, the key takeaways for us from today’s release are; (i) Management has flagged that the moderation in margins in the current year will be “more pronounced” than FY19 (-110bps) which is a steeper decline than we currently have pencilled in (-60bps); (ii) The forward order book is down 4% yoy in unit terms (see chart below) which management attributes to good on site progress (+1% in Aug, +3% in June); (iii) Sales rates are robust at 183 reservations per week or +4% yoy. While activity levels in the market remain reasonable the margin commentary from Bellway implies that we will be trimming our forecasts by c. 3% for FY20.
Margin commentary will be a focus
Operating margins for FY19 declined by 110bps yoy (Goodbody 100bps) with H219 declining by 140bps. Management notes that in the absence of HPI and the one-off
benefit of Nine Elms to the operating margin coupled with continued build cost pressure, the moderation in margins “will be more pronounced” in the year ahead. Goodbody and consensus forecasts assume a c. 50-60bps decline which appears optimistic in this light.
